'''Jorge de Amorim Campos''' (born 17 August 1964), a.k.a. '''Jorginho''', is a Brazilian retired [[Association football|footballer]] who played mainly as a [[Defender (association football)#Full back|right back]], and is a current manager.
A quick, technically gifted, and hard-working full-back,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1994-06-15/features/9406150766_1_baggio-great-soccer-players-goals-in-world|title=Baggio Takes Great Strides Toward Soccer Greatness|publisher=The Orlando Sentinel|author1=Mike Zizzo|date=15 June 1994|accessdate=24 September 2015}}</ref> he is regarded as one of the best full-backs of his generation, and as one of the greatest Brazilian defenders of all time.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brazil's greatest defenders|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/18621/6120873/brazils-greatest-defenders|work=Sky Sports|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref> He played in his country for five different clubs, and also spent six years in Germany, namely with [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]; additionally, he was part of the [[Brazil national football team|Brazilian team]] that won the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994 World Cup]].
==Playing career== ===Club=== Born in [[Rio de Janeiro]], Jorginho started playing professionally for local side [[America Football Club (RJ)|América Football Club]], moving after just one season to [[Clube de Regatas do Flamengo]].
In 1989, he went overseas, joining German [[Bundesliga]] outfit [[Bayer 04 Leverkusen]]. With most teams in the country playing in a [[Formation (association football)|5–3–2 or 3–5–2 formation]], his tremendous offensive ability was put to good use, and he scored five goals for Bayer during [[1991–92 Bundesliga|his third and final season]].
Staying in the country, Jorginho signed with league giants [[FC Bayern Munich]] in [[1992–93 Bundesliga|1992–93]], backed by a defensive line which included [[Olaf Thon]], [[Thomas Helmer]] and later [[Lothar Matthäus]]. He won the national title in his second year but, after the loan return of [[Markus Babbel]], a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]] which also operated on [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|the right flank]], was restricted to just ten league contests in 1994–95.
After still appearing with success for [[J. League]]'s [[Kashima Antlers]], winning both [[J. League Division 1|the league]] and [[List of J-League Player of the Year|MVP]] titles in [[1996 J. League|1996]], Jorginho returned to Brazil and played until 39, with [[São Paulo FC]], [[CR Vasco da Gama]] and [[Fluminense Football Club]]. In 2001, he paired at Vasco with both [[Romário]] and [[Bebeto]], but did not seem to get along with the pair.
===International=== Jorginho was capped 64 times for the [[Brazil national football team|Brazilian national team]], scoring three goals. He played at both the [[1990 FIFA World Cup|1990]] and the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994]] [[FIFA World Cup]]s.
In the latter edition, he played all the matches as the nation emerged victorious. Jorginho was [[Penalty card#Yellow card|booked]] in the second-round match against the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]], but was named in the [[FIFA World Cup awards#All-Star Team|All-Star squad]] a few days later. He contributed two assists in the tournament, including a cross in the semifinals against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] that helped Romário score the winning goal. He also performed solidly against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in the [[1994 FIFA World Cup Final|final]], including a play in which he freed himself from a double-team. However, he got injured after just twenty minutes of play, and was replaced by [[Cafú]].
In 2006, Jorginho was hired as the head coach of first side América. However, on 31 July of that same year, he was hired as Brazil's assistant, joining the staff of former national side teammate [[Dunga]]. In two 2008 [[Exhibition game|friendlies]], he took over for the head manager, following Dunga's dismissal in the previous game and subsequent ban from the [[Brazilian Football Confederation]]; he led the team to two 1–0 wins, against the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] and Sweden.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=480289&cc=4716 | title = Dunga banned for four games by Brazilian tribunal | publisher = [[ESPN Soccernet]] | date = 8 November 2007 | accessdate = 19 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/braz-coach-triv.html | title = Brazilian National Team Coaches | publisher = [[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate = 19 February 2012}}</ref> Both left the national team following the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]] quarterfinal loss against [[Netherlands national football team|Holland]].
Internationally, Jorginho also helped [[Brazil Olympic football team|the Olympic team]] [[Football at the 1988 Summer Olympics|win silver]] at the [[1988 Summer Olympics]] in [[Seoul]].<ref>{{FIFA player|63515}}</ref>
==Managerial career== Jorginho started his managerial career with his first club America in 2005. In the following year, he was appointed [[Dunga]]'s assistant at the [[Brazil national football team|Brazil national team]], remaining with the role until 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://extra.globo.com/esporte/auxiliar-d-dunga-entre-2006-2010-na-selecao-jorginho-elogia-escolha-da-cbf-13338689.html|title=Auxiliar de Dunga entre 2006 e 2010 na seleção, Jorginho elogia escolha da CBF|trans-title=Dunga's assistant between 2006 and 2010 at the ''Seleção'', Jorginho praises CBF's choice|publisher=Extra|language=pt|date=22 July 2014|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
On 30 August 2010, Jorginho was announced as the new [[Goiás Esporte Clube|Goiás]] manager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.com.br/noticia/145208_jorginho-e-o-novo-tecnico-do-goias-e-tem-apresentacao-marcada-para-esta-segunda-feira|title=Jorginho é o novo técnico do Goiás e tem apresentação marcada para esta segunda-feira|trans-title=Jorginho is the new manager of Goiás and has presentation scheduled for this Monday|publisher=[[ESPN Brasil]]|language=pt|date=30 August 2010|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> Dismissed on 8 November,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globoesporte.globo.com/futebol/times/goias/noticia/2010/11/jorginho-e-demitido-do-goias-e-arthur-neto-e-o-novo-treinador.html|title=Jorginho é demitido do Goiás, e Arthur Neto já é o novo treinador|trans-title=Jorginho is fired from Goiás, and Arthur Neto already is the new manager|publisher=Globo Esporte|language=pt|date=8 November 2010|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> he was appointed manager of [[Figueirense FC|Figueirense]] the following 1 March.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/jorginho-o-novo-tecnico-do-figueirense-2817145|title=Jorginho é o novo técnico do Figueirense|trans-title=Jorginho is the new manager of Figueirense|publisher=[[O Globo]]|language=pt|date=1 March 2011|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
On 21 December 2011, Jorginho left ''Figueira'' and was named at the helm of Kashima Antlers, a club he already represented as a player.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globoesporte.globo.com/futebol/noticia/2011/12/jorginho-confirma-acerto-com-kashima-antlers.html|title=Técnico Jorginho confirma acerto com o Kashima Antlers|trans-title=Manager Jorginho confirms deal with Kashima Antlers|publisher=Globo Esporte|language=pt|date=21 December 2011|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> He returned to Brazil on 17 March 2013, being appointed [[Clube de Regatas do Flamengo|Flamengo]] manager,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flamengo.com.br/noticias/futebol/jorginho-e-o-novo-tecnico-do-flamengo|title=Jorginho é o novo técnico do Flamengo|trans-title=Jorginho is the new manager of Flamengo|publisher=CR Flamengo|language=pt|date=17 March 2013|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> but was sacked on 6 June.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/campeonato-brasileiro-2013/jorginho-demitido-do-flamengo-8606553|title=Jorginho é demitido do Flamengo|trans-title=Jorginho is fired from Flamengo|publisher=O Globo|language=pt|date=6 June 2013|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
Jorginho was subsequently in charge of [[Associação Atlética Ponte Preta|Ponte Preta]] and [[Al-Wasl F.C.|Al-Wasl]] before being named manager of former club Vasco on 16 August 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.com.br/noticia/536089_jorginho-e-o-novo-treinador-do-vasco-e-ja-comanda-treino-nesta-segunda|title=Jorginho é o novo treinador do Vasco e já comanda treino nesta segunda|trans-title=Jorginho is the new manager of Vasco and already takes over trainings this Monday|publisher=ESPN Brasil|language=pt|date=16 August 2015|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> Despite failing to [[2015 Campeonato Brasileiro Série A|avoid relegation]], he was maintained and won the [[2016 Campeonato Carioca]]; after [[2016 Campeonato Brasileiro Série B|achieving immediate promotion]], he resigned on 28 November 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globoesporte.globo.com/futebol/times/vasco/noticia/2016/11/apos-quase-um-ano-e-meio-jorginho-conversa-com-eurico-e-acerta-saida.html|title=Após quase um ano e meio, Jorginho conversa com Eurico e acerta saída|trans-title=After nearly one-and-a-half year, Jorginho talks with Eurico and agrees departure|publisher=Globo Esporte|language=pt|date=28 November 2016|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
On 1 June 2017 Jorginho was appointed manager of [[Esporte Clube Bahia|Bahia]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esporteclubebahia.com.br/jorginho/|title=Novo comando|trans-title=New command|publisher=EC Bahia|language=pt|date=1 June 2017|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> but his reign only lasted nearly two months.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globoesporte.globo.com/ba/futebol/times/bahia/noticia/apos-derrota-para-o-sport-bahia-demite-jorginho.ghtml|title=Após derrota para o Sport, Bahia demite Jorginho|trans-title=After defeat to Sport, Bahia dismiss Jorginho|publisher=Globo Esporte|language=pt|date=31 July 2017|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> The following 21 May he replaced fired [[Marcelo Chamusca]] at the helm of [[Ceará Sporting Club|Ceará]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cearasc.com/noticia/jorginho-e-o-novo-treinador-cearasc|title=Jorginho é o novo treinador do Ceará para a temporada 2018|trans-title=Jorginho is the new manager of Ceará for the 2018 season|publisher=Ceará SC|language=pt|date=21 May 2018|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> but resigned on 4 June after alleging "personal reasons";<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cearasc.com/noticia/jorginho-nao-e-mais-treinador-do-ceara|title=Jorginho não é mais treinador do Ceará|trans-title=Jorginho is no longer manager of Ceará|publisher=Ceará SC|language=pt|date=4 June 2018|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> the day after his resignation, he was announced back at Vasco.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/jorginho-anunciado-como-novo-tecnico-do-vasco-22749277|title=Jorginho é anunciado como novo técnico do Vasco|trans-title=Jorginho is announced as new manager of Vasco|publisher=O Globo|language=pt|date=5 June 2018|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
Jorginho was fired on 13 August 2018, after only 10 matches.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globoesporte.globo.com/futebol/times/vasco/noticia/jorginho-nao-e-mais-o-tecnico-do-vasco.ghtml|title=Durou pouco: após 10 jogos, Jorginho é demitido do Vasco|trans-title=It did not last long: after 10 matches, Jorginho is fired from Vasco|publisher=Globo Esporte|language=pt|date=13 August 2018|access-date=14 August 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Jorginho is a born-again Christian. Alongside compatriots [[Cláudio Taffarel]] and [[Bismarck Barreto Faria|Bismarck]] – also footballers – he was featured sharing his faith in a special version of the film ''[[Jesus (1979 film)|Jesus]]'', produced and distributed during the [[1998 FIFA World Cup|1998 World Cup]].
He also founded the club ''Bola Pra Frente'' in his Rio de Janeiro [[slum]] of Guadalupe.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.stern.de/reise/fernreisen/rio-de-janeiro-die-wiege-der-fussballgoetter-555336.html | title = Rio de Janeiro: Die Wiege der Fußballgötter |trans-title=Rio de Janeiro: The Gods of football's cradle | publisher = [[Stern (magazine)|Stern]] | date = 21 February 2006 | language = German | accessdate = 19 February 2012}}</ref>
==Managerial statistics== <ref>[https://data.j-league.or.jp/SFIX07/?staff_id=4092 J.League Data Site]{{ja}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" !rowspan="2"|Team !rowspan="2"|From !rowspan="2"|To !colspan="5"|Record |- !G!!W!!D!!L!!Win % |- |align="left"|[[Kashima Antlers]] |align="left"|2012 |align="left"|2012 {{WDL|34|12|10|12}} |- !colspan="3"|Total {{WDLtot|34|12|10|12}} |}
